src package

src.HIVModel module

class src.HIVModel.HIVOpen(beta, sigma, nu, mu, delta, gamma)[source]

Bases: object

A class implementing an open SEIRS (Susceptible-Exposed-Infectious-Recovered-Susceptible) model for HIV.

This class implements a modified SEIRS epidemiological model that accounts for population dynamics, HIV transmission, and treatment effects. The model includes birth rates, natural death rates, and HIV-related mortality.

beta

Infection rate parameter

Type:

float

sigma

Rate of progression from exposed to infectious state

Type:

float

nu

Recovery rate due to Anti-retroviral Therapies (ART)

Type:

float

mu

Natural death rate

Type:

float

delta

HIV-related death rate

Type:

float

gamma

Rate at which recovered individuals become susceptible again

Type:

float

results

Storage for simulation results

Type:

pandas.DataFrame

columns

Mapping between model parameters and data column names

Type:

dict

param_samples

Storage for parameter samples during calibration

Type:

list

calibrate_parameters(num_bootstrap=100)[source]

Calibrate model parameters using bootstrapped historical data.

This method performs parameter calibration using bootstrap resampling of the historical data. It minimizes the mean squared error between observed and simulated values for infections, deaths, and recovered cases.

Parameters:

num_bootstrap (int, optional) – Number of bootstrap samples to use. Defaults to 100.

Returns:

Contains three elements:

  • numpy.ndarray: Mean simulated values for infections

  • numpy.ndarray: Mean simulated values for recovered cases

  • numpy.ndarray: Mean simulated values for deaths

Return type:

tuple

Note

This method also creates three plots comparing observed vs simulated values and saves them as PNG files: ‘infections_fit3.png’, ‘deaths_fit3.png’, and ‘recovered_fit3.png’

load_data(data, columnDictionary)[source]

Load and preprocess data for the model.

This method loads either a CSV file or DataFrame and maps the columns to the required model parameters. It also initializes the model’s compartments and demographic parameters based on the first row of data.

Parameters:

  • data (Union[str, pandas.DataFrame]) – Either a path to a CSV file or a pandas DataFrame

  • columnDictionary (dict) – Dictionary mapping model parameters to column names in the data. Required keys are: [‘population’, ‘new_infections’, ‘total_hiv’, ‘viral_suppression’, ‘deaths_hiv’, ‘number_of_births’, ‘natural_death_rate’]

Raises:

ValueError – If data is neither a string nor DataFrame, or if required columns are missing

Note

This method sets several instance attributes including S0, E0, I0, R0, D0 (initial compartment values) and b, d, art (demographic parameters)

simulate(years, initial_conditions=None, params=None)[source]

Simulate the SEIRS model for a specified number of years.

This method solves the system of differential equations that define the SEIRS model using numerical integration. It can use either default or custom initial conditions and parameters.

Parameters:

  • years (int) – Number of years to simulate

  • initial_conditions (list, optional) – List of initial values [S0, E0, I0, R0, D0]. Defaults to None, using values from loaded data.

  • params (list, optional) – List of model parameters [beta, sigma, nu, mu, delta, gamma]. Defaults to None, using instance parameters.

Returns:

Simulation results containing columns for Year, Exposed,

Infectious, Recovered (ART), and Deaths (HIV)

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

Raises:

ValueError – If data hasn’t been loaded before simulation

Note

The returned DataFrame includes yearly values for all compartments and can be accessed via the instance’s results attribute

simulate_with_uncertainty(years)[source]

Simulate the model with uncertainty quantification.

This method runs multiple simulations using the calibrated parameter samples to generate mean predictions with confidence intervals. It creates a plot showing the mean and 95% confidence intervals for all compartments.

Parameters:

years (int) – Number of years to simulate forward

Raises:

ValueError – If parameter samples don’t exist (calibration hasn’t been run)

Note

Creates and saves a plot as ‘SEIRS_results3.png’ showing predictions with confidence intervals for all compartments

src.clean_data module

class src.clean_data.PopulationDataPreprocessor(population_filepath, viral_filepath)[source]

Bases: object

A class to handle the preprocessing of population and viral suppression data.

This class provides functionality to load, process, and analyze population and viral suppression data from CSV files. It includes methods for data cleaning, prediction of viral suppression rates, and adjustment of historical data.

population_filepath

Path to the population data CSV file

Type:

str

viral_filepath

Path to the viral suppression data CSV file

Type:

str

pop_df

DataFrame containing population data

Type:

pandas.DataFrame

viral_df

DataFrame containing viral suppression data

Type:

pandas.DataFrame

logistic_function

Fitted logistic function for predictions

Type:

callable

params

Parameters of the fitted logistic function

Type:

tuple

cdc_years

Array of years with CDC viral suppression data

Type:

numpy.ndarray

cdc_values

Array of CDC viral suppression values

Type:

numpy.ndarray

cdc_data

Dictionary mapping years to CDC viral suppression values

Type:

dict

adjust_viral_suppression()[source]

Adjust viral suppression values based on historical and predicted data.

This method creates adjusted viral suppression values using a combination of historical data, CDC data points, and logistic function predictions.

Returns:

DataFrame containing adjusted viral suppression values

for years 1990-2021

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

fit_logistic_curve()[source]

Fit logistic function to CDC data points.

This method fits a logistic function to the CDC viral suppression data points using scipy’s curve_fit function.

Returns:

A tuple containing:

  • callable: The fitted logistic function

  • tuple: The optimal parameters (L, x0, k)

Return type:

tuple

load_population_data()[source]

Load and preprocess population data from CSV file.

This method reads the population data CSV file, transposes it for proper formatting, and calculates additional metrics including births and deaths.

Returns:

Processed population data with calculated metrics

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

load_viral_data()[source]

Load and preprocess viral suppression data from CSV file.

This method reads the viral suppression data CSV file, transposes it for proper formatting, and converts the year column to integer type.

Returns:

Processed viral suppression data

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

predict_early_viral_suppression(years_to_predict)[source]

Predict viral suppression values for early years using linear regression.

Parameters:

years_to_predict (list) – Years to predict viral suppression values for

Returns:

Updated viral suppression DataFrame with predicted values

for early years

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

process_data()[source]

Execute the main data processing workflow.

This method orchestrates the complete data processing workflow, including: 1. Loading population and viral suppression data 2. Fitting the logistic curve 3. Predicting early years 4. Adjusting viral suppression values 5. Combining all processed data

Returns:

Final processed DataFrame containing population data

with adjusted viral suppression values

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

src.clean_data.main()[source]

Run the preprocessing workflow.

This function instantiates the PopulationDataPreprocessor class with the appropriate file paths, processes the data, and saves the results to a CSV file.
